awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Conference: Workshop on Computational Structural Biology 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
The Computational Structural Bioinformatics Workshop (CSBW) is a single-track, one-day workshop featuring peer-reviewed works on advances in computational methods in structural biology. Understanding the fundamental role of protein and nucleotide structures in life processes involves many computational challenges. It is held as part of the IEEE-Bioinformatics and Biomedicine. New experimental and computational techniques that generate and use large amounts of structural data have enabled novel analysis approaches, leading to an increased understanding of different biophysical phenomena. CSBW provides a forum for discussion of the newest computational approaches related to protein structure discovery and analysis. Structural biology is an interdisciplinary field, and CSBW connects scientists who work on this topic through the lens of various academic areas, such as computer science, bioinformatics, biochemistry, and computational biology. One of the main goals of the proposed workshop is to connect undergraduate and graduate students to the  computational bioinformatics community, giving them an opportunity to present their work to top scientists in  the field and to network with their peers. Such interactions have a lasting impact in a student’s academic life, as they expose students to state-of-the-art research and creates the professional connections needed for career advancement.

The proposed workshop will bring together senior researchers and students working on exploring the relationships between sequence, structure and protein function via computational structural bioinformatics. The workshop will showcase the newest developments on a diverse set of problems and computational methods, including: Structure representation, prediction, and alignment, biomolecular interaction and docking, molecular dynamics simulations, biomolecular graphics, coarse-grained modeling, data mining of structural data, structural genomics, optimization in structural problems, high-performance computing in modeling, graph theory applied to structural problems, and biomolecular structure refinement. The participation of researchers from diverse backgrounds will advance understanding of common scientific themes and may facilitate collaborations around shared research goals. Papers accepted to the workshop will be published in IEEE Xplore Digital Library. Workshop participants will also receive invitations for a special issue in a peer-reviewed journal.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The field of Computational Structural Bioinformatics has experienced rapid growth in the past few years due to the impact of novel computational techniques on expanding our understanding of molecular life processes.  To address these issues and discuss the latest technology in computational structural biology, the 15th Computational Structural Bioinformatics Workshop (CSBW) was held in Las Vegas, NV, as part of IEEE-BIBM, on December 6th, 2022. The program of the full-day workshop included invited talks, contributed talks, and a panel session. It was the first CSBW workshop held in person since 2020, but with an online component that allowed participants to join the workshop virtually as well.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes: The workshop received over 30 submissions, of which 15 were accepted via a rigorous peer-review process as contributed talks. Corresponding research papers were published in the IEEE-BIBM conference proceedings. Workshop participants were also invited to submit an extended version of their papers to a Special Issue: Recent Advances in Computational Structural Bioinformatics, in the International Journal of Molecular Sciences, MDPI. Special invited talks by Dr. Ron Dror and Dr. Brian Y. Chen were very well received by the workshop attendees, as they highlighted the state-of-the-art of structural bioinformatics.

Broader Impacts Outcomes: To promote the interactions of students with their peers and experts in the field of computational structural bioinformatics, the award managed by the University of New Mexico sponsored 7 graduate students to attend the conference, with maximum support amount of $1250 per student. These students originated from 5 different US academic institutions, 3 of which were Minority Serving Institutions. Students had a unique opportunity to present their research to leaders in the field, and to connect with other students working on similar problems. As the first in-person CSBW workshop since 2020, financially supporting students to attend the workshop was crucial to provide a venue for networking that could lead to future collaborations and professional advancement. One of the highlights of the workshop was a Panel Session on the future of computational bioinformatics and the impact of artificial intelligence tools in the field. Students participated heavily in the panel discussion, with panel participants Dr. Filip Jagodzinski and Dr. Jing He providing critical insight on the role of academia in the field and how students and professors can navigate the fast-paced advancement of computational structural bioinformatics. The full-day workshop was held in a single room, allowing participants to spend the day together forming professional bonds. The workshop website provided critical information for the participants. The success of CSBW 2022 led to the workshop being continued in 2023 as part of the ACM-BCB 2023 conference in Houston, TX. By combining state-of-the-art research presentations and networking opportunities for students in the field of computational structural biology, CSBW greatly benefits the field by fostering community, collaboration, and development of high-impact research.


Last Modified: 03/29/2024
Modified by: Bruna D Jacobson
